ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture that was recorded and a virtual seminar once a week.

some combination; when my internet connection was wonky, I would watch the recordings after 
There were also live discussion sections.
There were a few recorded lectures due to schedule conflicts.
Live virtual sections.
Lectures were recorded. Section was on zoom
We also had weekly section meetings with a teaching fellow held over zoom.
Lecture was also recorded so that it could be accessed later.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about architectural styles throughout the Modern era.
An appreciation for architecture.

I learned a lot about modern architecture; the themes that have driven it, and how it's much more of a lineage pulling from past ideas and practices, than i had expected. The images in the class were gorgeous and I'm grateful that I got exposure to them. The readings were surprisingly wonderful, and Craig Buckley is an insanely engaging lecturer.
I gained the knowledge of how sociocultural and political developments influence the establishment of certain architectural motifs.
History of modern architecture
I liked that this course took an international perspective when analyzing architectural trends throughout history.

I gained a broad knowledge of modern architecture, its influences and historical implications. The course also provided background on a plethora of architects through readings of architectural manifestos. I enjoyed that lectures emphasized visual material alongside instructor description, which allowed me to gain language skills to describe various structures and interiors.
I developed a broad understanding of architecture throughout the past centuries.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very engaging and interesting course. I especially enjoyed how small the sections were because they felt more engaging and facilitated great conversations. The final project was a really fun way to put everything I learned all semester together.

I learned how to analyze buildings from a big-picture perspective down to the details. This is really great and has changed how I experience and view cities. I learned how to speak cogently about the lineages behind different design styles and ideas, and got a great overlook of modern design. Weaknesses-the first two papers (particularly the literary analysis of a primary source doc by a designer) were a little confusing, as I wasn't sure what to focus on in them. However, the timeline project and prospectus was fantastic and a great way of synthesizing info and exploring an idea important to you. I loved how the "prospectus" helped us peer forward into the project and get detailed feedback before the final.

This course benefits from not focusing on the materiality of architecture. However, I do wish there was a more diverse survey of architecture with respect to gender and race/ethnicity (though it may be a hard task since it seems "modern architecture" was dominated by a certain demographic)
This course was easy to follow and  well organized

This class was interesting and provided a broad survey of modern architecture. It traced a variety of themes throughout times to present of cohesive analysis of the trends. I think that a weakness of the class is the variability in grading between TAs and the uneven size of sections, given that some sections had as few as 5 students while others were much larger.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked how the lectures were live and recorded, so you had options. Small sections were nice to fell engaged in the content.

The live discussion sections were very productive, and my TF, Kevin, was wonderful in recapping the themes we'd discussed, and came up with a fantastic format for our live discussions (a PDF download of slides,so we could still see him and participate while opening the image on our own laptops)

I appreciated when Professor Buckley would prompt the class for analysis and responses, but I think it should happen more consistently. I also wish we had utilized breakout rooms during lectures to facilitate discussion and exchange more throughout the week.
Professor Buckley would occasionally ask students to come off mute or to use an online poll to participate.
I think the recorded lecture style worked very well, and it was quite useful to be able to retroactively re-watch lectures to help with the essays / final annotated timeline.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! This is the best class I have taken at Yale so far! Take this!! Prof. Buckley was always a joy to listen to and his lectures were so interesting. The papers and project were actually enjoyable to complete. I have such a greater appreciation for architecture and look at buildings differently after. Totally changed my perspective.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It was a lot of fun, the projects were very self-directed, and I learned about modern architecture in a way that's reshaped how I approach design today. Also, some of the images we went through were truly astonishing, and their visual images will stick around in my mind for a very long time -- i can tell!

I enrolled thinking it would be a survey course on the history of architecture, which is not really what the course is.  I certainly learned about big architectural ideas, but the syllabus is rooted in theory, which was frustrating.
Recommend if new to architecture and hope to appreciate its beauty
Yes I would. It was interested
I would recommend this course to another student. The assignments were varied and interesting, and the lectures were engaging even in a virtual format.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is very interested in architecture. As someone who was coming into this class with only a introductory level of knowledge about architecture, I often found it a bit difficult to keep up and remember all the terms.
